description.text:
Based on the following projects:

  • Rostock Mini Pro (CZAR) thingiverse
  • Rostock Mini (bwevans) thingiverse
  • Rostock (Johann) thingiverse, github

Used Software:

  • OpenSCAD 2015.10.17
  • Inkscape 0.91

Improvements in comparison to the Mini Pro:

  • openSCAD-code base reworked
    • more modular design and more parametric
    • better documentation
    • cleaner code, no missing dependencies, less dead code
    • it's easier to make own mods
  • included bill of material and links (for orientation)
  • included marlin-config (for orientation)
  • included redesign of bottom and top plate (Inkscape svg)
  • more space under the printer (there is just USB and power coming out of mine)
    • this design allows shorter wires to the motors and results in better EMC
    • shock absorbing standoffs (if printed with soft PLA)
    • better cooling for motors
    • allows active cooling for motor-drivers
  • better stability, less wiggle, stiffer frame, better print-quality
    • better fin-design for all plate-connecting parts
    • design of hotend-mount is much more sturdy
    • allow two lm8uu per rod (4 per carriage)
  • the fan of the E3D-Hotend fits between hotend-mount and platform
    • hotend is lifted and print-space in z-direction is bigger
  • included space / cutout for nuts on more places
  • hal-sensor-end-stops with better repeatability
  • better cable-management
  • includes a filament-holder on top of the printer
  • direct mounting at carriage of open belt-ends with zip-ties (with belt_mount_for_carriage.scad)
    • groves secure belt-mount
  • built in power-switch next to the heat-bed

Sources

Follow the Link to Github

Printer:

delta mini pro 2

title: Four Sided Awesome Disposable Utility Blade

description.text:
I was getting tired of always having to change the blade in my utility knife. I thought to my self; wouldn't it be great if I could just print a disposable version that I could just chuck once the blade was dull?

Now, I know what you're thinking; we have enough disposable goods in our society filling up our landfills and destroying the earth!!! I don't want to be labeled as some climate-change denying touch-hole that doesn't care about the environment so I decided I would make it eco-friendly by adding three more blades to it. This makes it last much longer and causes less waste!!!.

Once all four blades are dull you can just throw it away without feeling so guilty! Speaking of throwing, my friends tell me that this thing looks a lot like some sort of throwing star. I don't see it, but to be on the safe side: please do not throw this thing at anybody... that would be über lame.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20 - 25% or whatever

Notes:

Print the bottom.stl and top.stl files. Glue the blades into each printed piece with superglue or epoxy. Next glue the two halves together and clamp.

Alternatively you can print it all as one piece using the full.stl file and insert the blades during the print. Two pauses will have to be inserted into the gcode.

  • Slice the file at .2mm layer height.

  • Find where the layer at 2mm ends and insert the following code;

    G91 ; Put in relative mode
    G1 Z10 ; Lower bed by 10mm
    G90 ; Put back in absolute mode
    G1 X0 Y0 ; Zero (home) the X & Y
    M0 Click to Restart ; Pause and wait for the user
    G91 ; Put in relative mode
    G1 Z-10 ; Raise the bed back up 10mm
    G90 ; Put back in absolute mode

  • Then find where the layer at 2.8 mm ends and insert the same.

It helps to cover the top side of the blades with Aqua Net so that the plastic will stick. Be careful when inserting the blades into the print if you have a heated bed, they get hot quick.

I have included a gcode file that already has the pauses in it. It was created by Slic3r with a layer height of .2mm using a .4mm nozzle. Also the skirt and brim are turned on.

2) If you want the Audiometric spec rings then just drop the Y to 1mm from 4mm and print the same model. You can glue it to the main body.

Created in TinkerCad from Ruler Dimensions.
Working on a small box for holding an Arduino and a switch. The switch is from Adafruit.

The Bowtie is a novel space-filling solid. Sets of these pieces can be assembled into interesting shapes. The original design is by Robert Reid. I presented a paper on this, and the derivation of a whole class of new space-filling solids, at Gathering for Gardner 9.

The Bowtie was invented by my friend Robert Reid. We wrote a paper about this, that I presented at Gathering For Gardner 9. The Bowtie is an example of a class of solid that fills space. You can make a nice puzzle from a set of the 5Hcolumn3 file: print 9 in one colour, 6 in another colour, 4 in a final colour, and assemble them to make a cube as shown in the 1st picture above. Its not trivial to do as the pieces can go in in a couple of wrong orientations. George Miller might have been the first to suggest trying to do this in a closed box (I believe he made some of these for Robert a few years ago). These pieces are easy to print on most printers. I would stand the pieces up on their end and use a raft to make them stable. There is a minor risk that a piece will get knocked over when you print, so I would suggest not printing too many at once.

description.text:
Always looking for batteries? I was until I designed and printed these battery holders. The AA battery holder holds 36 AA cells and the AAA battery holder holds 48 AAA cells. For use in my shop I glued on cleat clips that allow me to easily hang the battery holders on the wall high enough to keep them away from a 4 year old.

The holders were printed in ABS as well as the cleat clips.

The batteries are easily filled from the top and give a clear indication of the quantity remaining as well as providing a first in first out delivery.

comments.text: Having already experienced catastrophic layer delamination on previous projects, I'd suggest printing this with the face down so the layers run perpendicular to that of the photo.  I can just see adding batteries to the top only to have the bottom delaminate, dropping the contents.  Good job on the design though, I like it.

This is a backlit 11x17 picture frame I made on my laser cutter. There are four layers, the face, a 1/2" spacer, a reflector, and a back. I made the face using a combination of etching and cutting to ensure that it would hold together but let light shine through and mask a bit of the LEDs. The 1/2" spacer is perfect for a band of LEDs. The two back pieces hold the picture with the front one reflecting the light.

I cut the face frame using 1/4" Maple veneered MDF, and used a few coats of polyurethane. The spacer is 1/2" plywood. and the back two are 1/4" White melamine MDF. The outside dimensions are 15.5" x 21.5".

Initially I cut the spacer and back pieces in 4 pieces each but I found it difficult to glue them up square, so I recommend cutting them as single pieces.

title: Prusa i3 belt tensioner (and other printers should work)

description.text:
Note - all these types of clip on belt tensioning systems are a Temporary fix!! they will all cause vibrations in the belt which will feed back into the print a bit. proper stationary tensioning system is needed for quality prints.

••version 2 uploaded today July 13, 2016, lighter and a tad shorter. Noticed it high speed, small movements of the printer the belt vibrated and the tensioner was knocking into the carriage belt holder, didn't hurt anything was just unnecessary, annoying noise.••

Kinda took the idea from this one. felt it was actually adding too much tension on the belt so i made a lower tension version. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:81991

just a tad lighter tension on the belt than most. I was either getting too tight or too loose with the belt just trying to get it right during install.. tried the one above and it was really yanking on the whole system.. this is just a slight tad less..

(PS, ya.. got to vacuum around the printer!! LOL )

comments.text: Very nice . I needed this.
comments.author: jtaylor330

comments.text: just made a slightly lighter/shorter/smaller version as I noticed during some prints if there was high speed, small movements with it centered under the carriage it would knock into the belt holder. didn't hurt anything but the knocking noise is annoying. "shouldn't" do it anymore.
comments.author: jtaylor330

comments.text: :) me too, reason I tried the other one I linked 1st  :)  it worked OK but found it was stressing the whole system a bit too much. :)  glad this one is working for ya!

description.text: Files to print wing structures which are very similar to the original Estes Pegasus #0806 model rocket. The single wing is sized to the original. The scaled and mirrored wings are for direct attachment to a BT-5 body tube without an internal engine mount.

Printer:

Custom

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

High (0.3 to 0.2 mm layer height)

Infill:

Your choice, although I use ~30% to save weight.

Notes:

The scaled and mirrored wings may need support for the tube area, but this area is very thin and cleaning out support is difficult.

Assembly (Full Size)

Parts for the complete rocket can be purchased online. I bought body tubes, engine mount hooks, shock cord, parachute, and nose cone separately. For the full scale wings, print the original and a mirrored copy. Clean up as necessary. I used 5 min epoxy to attach the wing tips to the wings. These are dovetailed for strength, so some minor filing, sanding or cutting may be necessary. Glue the upper dorsal fins to the engine pods. Again, using 5 min epoxy, attach the completed wings to a BT20 body tube. Make sure to fillet the glue over extra area on the body tube for strength. Assemble the rest of the rocket according to the original instructions. (http://www.spacemodeling.org/jimz/est0806.htm)

The wings are much heavier than the original balsa wings. Each wing assembly weighs about as much as the complete original model. I used 13mm A10-3T Engines. These give a fantastic launch and recovery within a football field sized area. Do not use the smaller 13mm engines like 1/2A3 or 1/4A3 engines. The model is just too heavy and your rocket will usually end up nose down in the ground before the parachute is deployed.

Assembly (Mini)

Parts for the complete rocket can be purchased online. I bought the body tube and parachute separately. I printed a nice nose cone from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:559583.

Print the scaled and mirrored wings. These are scaled down to ~75% of the original to fit directly to a BT-5 body tube. Clean up as necessary. The wing assembly has two small protrusions inside the round body tube attachment area. These are to prevent a motor from being inserted too far into the body tube. I used 5 min epoxy to attach the wing tips to the wings. These are dovetailed for strength, so some minor filing, sanding or cutting may be necessary. Glue the upper dorsal fins to the engine pods. Again, using 5 min epoxy, attach the completed wings to a BT-5 body tube. I had issues with the motor releasing from the tube so you may want to assemble with an engine hook glued under the wing assembly.

This model is very light. I easily used 13mm 1/2A3 engines and the model FLEW off the launchpad. My only issue was that without an engine hook, the engine would release from the body tube instead of deploying the parachute due to the tight fit of the parachute in the body tube. I would recommend an engine hook and the use of very thin shock cord or fishing line as well as a streamer instead of a parachute.

I designed the files by using the original instruction and layout cards from the kit. I drafted the parts on SolidWorks and then fine tuned and modified as necessary.

Future versions may be thinner through some areas to reduce weight.

Yo, Do you have a Samsung Galaxy Tab 8.9" or 10.1" tablet?? If so here is a full featured docking solution! At work we bought a fleet of 8.9 LTE Tab's and I immediately began creation of a dock that would work with a naked unit or with a TPU case on it. Each dock has an adapter locking center channel and cable tunnel for the 30 pin power/data cable. I included 2 40mm unique dowels so you can easily slide the unit apart for addition and removal of the cable. The unit holds your Tab at a 20 degree angle perfect for desk usage or next to the bed. I widened the stance with the rear wedges so you can rest assured there will be no tipping even if your a hardcore screen basher. There are also dual front and rear speaker ports so you can mega jam even when docked with the 8.9! I have uploaded 2 different solutions that work on each tablet variant (not physically tested on the 10.1 but the qualifying dimensions are the same): 1.) A standard sized dock that minimizes plastic used and print duration. This dock allows you to grip the side of the Tab in the dock and easily use a thumb keyboard without pulling it from the dock! 2.) A jumbo dock that goes almost to the edge of the 8.9 and looks like a dock that you might buy at a retailer (or at least I like to think so...). All docks pictured with logos were on my beta units only and all uploaded docks are free of any branding. I have also attached my Sketchup master for your modding pleasures.

Make up your mind using the description above: Go standard:
-Print "GalTabDockLeft.stl" and "GalTabDockRight.stl"
-Clean with a knife
-Insert connection dowels
-Insert data/power cable in to indention
-Push halves together
-Slide Tab in
-Enjoy home made dock-it-ization! Go Jumbo:
-Print "GalTabDockBigLeft.stl" and "GalTabDockBigRight.stl"
-Clean with a knife
-Insert connection dowels
-Insert data/power cable in to indention
-Push halves together
-Slide Tab in
-Show your friends your a regal tablet balla! Printed on: TOM # 4890
MK6+
1.75mm
.4 nozzle

author: dainalloyd

title: Folger Tech Kossel 2020 T-nut support to make Assembly of Frame easier

description.text:
After struggling to put the horizontal aluminum extrusions in without the tnuts rotating, I thought there should be a better way to do this. Since I have a 3d printer already, I started looking at an easier way to do this with an additional plastic part. I did have to run several test prints to get this tnut support to a nice fit. The little raised metal between the t-nuts holds this in place & the plastic part keeps the t-nuts in the correct orientation while assembling. It was quite easy to assembly the horizontal frame with these in place. The weight of 18 of these plastic supports is less than 0.4oz at 20% infill. I used eSun Black PLA+ for these parts.

I attached the openscad file, a STL file with 2x t-nut supports & one with 6x t-nut supports. I would print the 2x STL file 1st to see if it fits well for you & adjust the openscad file if it does not.

I also made some cutting & gluing plastic jigs for the arms that I will upload seperately.

comments.text: These really should not normally be needed. The T-nuts are tapered to rotate and lock into position on their own when tightened. To get them to self-lock you have to start with them loose enough that they can rotate, then you have to tighten the screw relatively quickly in order to spin the t-nuts in the frame. On this type of bracket doing it without a ball-end wrench is a huge exercise in frustration, so I can see why this alternative solution would be attractive.
comments.author: gork

comments.text: Sorry, but my version of the t-nuts will rotate 360 degrees within the slot.  I put the bottom aluminum extrusions in place on one side of the vertex parts without these in place & it was very frustrating to keep those T-nuts in the correct position.  I was very surprised that they would rotate once in the extrusion.  I did also use a ball-end wrench.  On the plus side of these t-nuts, you can insert them into the face of the slot after you no longer have access to inserting them into either end.  I know the V-Slot T-Nuts will not rotate once in place unless you use their drop in style t-nuts.
comments.author: gork

comments.text: Perhaps Folger Tech have changed the supplier of either the T-nuts or the extrusions in recent kits so that the geometry works out now and the nuts self-lock. I just assembled mine last week and the ones that came in my kit would not rotate past their locked 90 degree position. The short ends have a chamfer and a slight bevel that allows this. They are of course the same style of drop-in nut as the ones in your photo, but I can imagine the tolerances are such that it would be impossible to distinguish visually between a nut that would spin all the way around (like it's not supposed to) and one that would lock (like it's supposed to). Especially if you are buying cheap hardware in bulk as Folger Tech appears to have done for some specific parts.
comments.author: GeoDave

title: Replacement Hand Crank for BBQ Fan

description.text:
Because I lost the hand crank for my BBQ fan I made a replacement part.

It can also be used in all cases where a crank with a 6x6mm² four cornered shaft is needed.

Edit 19.11.2016:
Added an arm model with 5x6mm² pin on request of usernameisalreadytaken.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If possible use circular external fill in your print settings to improve the stability of the parts.

The 100% infill is necessary to make a strong connection from the arm to the four cornered shaft on it. With less infill the shaft will only be connected over the upper layers of the arm to the instable infill. This connection would break with minimal force.

Put the axle in the right direction through the arm and fix it with some super glue. Take care of a right angle of the axis to the arm.
Then shift the handle over the axle, give some drops super glue to the lock and press it into the axles end. Watch that no glue comes to the area contacting the handle. Otherwise the handle will be fixed and can't rotate.
Designed with FreeCAD

title: Cool Rubbings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Back in 1980 my grandparents bought me a toy - "Little Van Goes" by Tomy. This was a bunch of plastic plates that had raised images of van parts. You could combine three plates in a holder, put a piece of paper on it, and rub with a crayon to make the most awesome 70's vans you could imagine. There were others of this type of toy, but pretty much entirely fashion oriented: Fashion Plates, Barbie Fashion Plates, etc. Thirty-two years later I decided to make my own version of those types of toys, but this time as there is a community of makers, together we can overcome the problem with the originals: lack of variation in plates! Now we can design as many plates as we want: sleepy robot eyes, rabbit mouth, pig nose, googly eyes, parts made from kids' drawings, ornamental parts, ABCs, and so on! Have fun! Read more of my thought process and story here: http://wp.me/p2hTaI-K

PRINT! base.stl -- This is the main piece you'll need, and the longest to print. This holds up to three plates securely and allows you place a piece of paper overtop and rub with a crayon to get the image. crayonholder.stl -- This is a piece to hold a crayon. It's not needed, but makes it much easier. You'll need to remove the paper wrapper from the crayon to be able to do rubbings (this piece is sized to not fit a crayon with wrapper still on) topper.stl - This optional piece was made to help hold the paper in place over the base and plates. However, since you can't see through paper, it is hard to align and use. If you do use this, you'll need to cut the crayons to the length of the crayon holder, otherwise it won't fit in between the walls of this piece. Plates - print as many plates as you want! MAKE!! blankplate.stl and blankplate.skp - Use either of these blank plates as the base for your own plates! Simply add a design to the top of the blank plate, extruded to 1.6mm. I used line widths of 1mm to get a good image, but you could use other sizes if you want. Filled areas work good too.

title: The Pink and Green Domino Machine

description.text:
Who likes knocking down dominoes? Yeah!!!!!!

Who likes setting up dominoes to be knocked down? Boo!!!!!!

Who likes pink and green? Uh, well, there's granddaughters, grandsons, nieces, nephews, and, well, you get the picture...

If you're like our family (we love knocking dominoes down, but can't stand setting dominoes up to be knocked down), then "The Pink and Green Domino Machine" may be the answer for you too! Our kids, grandkids, nieces, nephews and other family members like this little pink and green domino dispensing machine, and we hope you and yours do also!

"The Pink and Green Domino Machine" is a "domino" dispensing machine. While it doesn't dispense commercial dominoes (well it will, but not with much success as the tolerances for commercial dominoes are not quite "standardized"), it does dispense the 3D printed dominoes in this design on almost any smooth, flat surface with 1" leading edge to leading edge spacing. If you have a steady hand and good aim, adding dominoes to the rack while "The Pink and Green Domino Machine" is in motion will keep it dispensing dominoes until you run out of 3D printed dominoes, run into an obstacle, or the batteries deplete! It misses on occasions, so it requires patience at times and close attention to the off switch, but after awhile, you'll find yourself as did we, building very long strings of dominoes with ease.

After seeing Mathias Wandel's "Lego domino row building machine" (https://woodgears.ca/domino/index.html, he's an excellent woodworker, check out his site), I decided to design, 3D print and assemble my own version so that I would be much less likely to forget how to put it back together if I dropped it or if the youngsters got a hold of it (20 or so printed pieces as opposed to hundreds)! If you're a Lego enthusiast, then by all means build his design as it is very impressive! But if you're a 3D printing enthusiast, then perhaps this thing is for you!

Video of prototype here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K12tqdOb0f0.

Video of prototype without "Canopy.stl", "Rack.stl", and "Domino.stl" which better illustrates the mechanism is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QT916TMgEgs.

Designed using Sketchup Make 2016 and printed on an Ultimaker 2 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Make absolutely sure your build plate is level and not too close to the print head as any "oozing" will negatively effect the operation of "The Pink and Green Domino Machine".

This is a tight tolerance build, so be prepared for post printing trimming, filing, sanding, etc.

If your printer has problems printing "Gear Drive Bevel.stl", either use supports or rotate it 180 degrees vertical.

Parts I purchased:

1) "SPST Micromini Toggle Switch" (Radio Shack #275-0624).

2) "4 "AAA" Battery Holder" (Radio Shack #270-00413).

3) 6vdc 60 RPM gear motor (Amazon "DC 6V 60 RPM High Torque Electric Replacement Gear Box Motor").

4) 8 #18 (1 3/16" O.D. x 15/16" I.D. by 1/8") o-rings (Amazon, box and/or hardware store, ).

5) 4 "AAA" batteries.

Tools and supplies I used:

1) Rubber mallet.

2) Small vise.

3) Flat punch set.

4) Modeling knife.

5) Small files.

6) Sandpaper.

7) Slip joint pliers.

8) Needle nose pliers.

9) Thick cyanoacrylate glue.

10) Cyanoacrylate accelerator.

Assembly:

Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required. If the tight fitting components are too loose, add a small dot of cyanoacrylate to each side of the pin, allow to dry completely (I use accelerator to speed the process), then try the fit again. Repeat until tight.

Assemble as per "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl". I perform the assembly task in the following order:

1) Install motor.

2) Install "Gear Motor.stl" onto the motor shaft. You will have to slide the motor out slightly to perform this step.

4) Install "Arm Slide.stl".

5) Install "Gear Slide Small.stl". Adjust the motor position fore and aft to make sure "Gear Slide Small.stl" and "Gear Motor.stl" align.

6) Install "Slide .stl" as shown. Again, at this stage you should have tested the slide and made sure it operates smoothly with no drag. I had to file the top of both slide guides in "Chassis.stl" to remove any stray filament.

6) Install "Pin Slide.stl" as shown.

7) Install "Gear Drive Axle Chassis.stl" onto "Axle Chassis.stl" in the position shown.

8) Install the assembled axle into the rear of "Chassis.stl" as shown.

9) Install 4 o-rings on two of "Wheel.stl", then press the two assemblies onto each end of the assembled axle that was previously installed into "Chassis.stl". Make sure the wheels and gear rotate smoothly.

10) Press "Gear Drive.stl" into "Gear Drive Bevel.stl".

11) Using "Axle Gear Drive.stl", assemble the "Gear Drive.stl" and "Gear Drive Bevel.stl" onto "Chassis.stl". Make sure the wheels and gears rotate smoothly.

12) While holding "Gear Slide Bevel.stl" in the position shown, slide "Gear Slide Large.stl" into position and into "Gear Slide Bevel.stl".

13) Install 4 o-rings onto the remaining two "Wheel.stl".

14) Install "Axle Chassis.stl" into the front of "Chassis.stl" as shown, then press the "Wheel.stl" assemblies onto each end of "Axle Chassis.stl". Make sure the wheels rotate smoothly.

15) Install batteries in the battery holder, then touch the wires to the motor terminal to make sure the assembly moves forward, if not, reverse the wires and test again. Once the proper orientation is determined, solder the battery pack black wire to the correct motor terminal, the battery back red wire to the one of the switch terminals, then a red wire between the remaining switch terminal and motor terminal. Once complete, set the battery holder into the battery holder tray on "Chassis.stl".

16) Press "Canopy.stl" into "Rack.stl" as shown.

17) Press the "Canopy.stl" and "Rack.stl" assembly onto "Chassis.stl" as shown.

18) Print as many "Domino.stl" as you desire, testing each printed domino buy placing in "Rack.stl" and making sure it slides smoothly from one end to the other. If not, trim, file and/or sand "Rack.stl", "Domino.stl" or both. Carefully inspect each domino to make sure there is no "oozing" remnants on the build plate side of the domino (this will be a small bead of filament that squeezes out on the first layer if the print head is too close to the build plate). If detected, carefully remove it with a modeling knife, file and/or sandpaper as this is the most common cause of dominoes falling over or jamming in "Rack.stl".

Lubricate all moving surfaces with light machine oil.

Best of luck, and if you have any questions or comments, please feel free to comment and I will do my best to answer.

Hope you like it!

For traction, I decided to design wheels that used two #18 o-rings. The circumference of a #18 o-ring mounted on my wheel design is approximately 4". I next determined by trial and error that the distance between the dominoes I designed and printed worked best with a separation of approximately 1" leading to leading edge. Using these two parameters, I needed to design "The Pink And Green Domino Machine" gear train to eject 4 dominoes for every 1 rotation of the wheels.

So i designed "Gear Motor.stl" and "Gear Slide Small.stl" with the same number of gear teeth, 10, which results in a 1 to 1 gear ratio. Then I designed "Gear Slide Large.stl" such that it had 40 teeth, which results in a 4 to 1 gear ratio. Since "Gear Slide Small.stl" drives "Slide.stl" at the motor speed, and "Gear Slide Large.stl" has 4 times the number of teeth as "Gear Slide Small.stl", and all subsequent gears in the wheel drive train are 1 to 1, then the slide mechanism operates 4 times for each 1 wheel rotation.

That's easy, right?

I've received a few questions about the design, and here are my replies:

1) Why the limited size of "Rack.stl"? The answer is dominoes in the rack create friction on the surface that "The Pink And Green Domino Machine" runs on. If there are too many dominoes in the rack, the friction is so great that the machine turns to the right since the rack is offset from center. After trial and error, I determined 12 dominoes was as much as this mechanism could push without creating enough drag to lose traction and turn right.

2) Why did you print your own dominoes? It's cheaper to print them, my kids, grandkids, nieces and nephews have a much easier task racking a "thicker" domino, you can pick your own colors, and finally, a thicker domino is less apt to fall over.

3) Why does the last domino more often than not come out "crooked"? That's because the last domino has no previous domino holding it "square" in the rack. I considered a gate, but the drag of the gate would cause the dominoes to fall in the rack. I also considered decreasing the rack width, but with the variety of printer resolutions out there, I was hesitant to do so.

4) In the video, the last green domino almost falls over, why? Because when I printed the dominoes, I had yet to trim off the "ooze" bead.

5) What is the purpose of "Canopy.stl"? The intent was to keep the left and right arms of "Rack.stl" parallel.

6) Why is the assembly "Rack.stl" and "Canopy.stl" a separate part from "Chassis.stl"? Two reasons, the rack is at a higher plane than "Chassis.stl", and more important, If your dominoes fall over in the rack, and the slide mechanism is about to become jammed, the "Rack.stl" and "Canopy.stl" assembly will separate from "Chassis.stl" in order to avoid breaking "Rack.stl"

Because we all know bolo ties are "in" right now, right?
The slide is made to fit the thicker "shoelace" type cord, rather than the thinner leather cord some might use; the slides are incredibly easy to design once you get the measurements, so either let me know or fire up a free Tinkercad account and slap one together yourself.
The curvature on the slides coupled with the small size mean that (at least in my experience) they can be printed without interior supports, so I would set these to be printed with supports "touching baseplate only", as Cura puts it. You can paint the raised designs, or if you catch it in time pause it and swap the reels out for a nice contrast; I suggest classic Jurassic Park yellow and red.

e-Nable hands have all used "tippies" (silicone fingertips) as part of the delivered piece. This is a remix utilizing Phoenix Smooth fingers modified to incorporate molded silicone fingertips. Early tests have worked great - good fingertip gripping and quite sturdy. The idea can be modified to fit any e-Nable finger design quite easily and the fingertip mold is included here. All files are 100% and can be scaled to fit.
The fingertips have two holes printed within that look like the bottom of a thermometer bulb. This makes the base larger than the tube which will not then pull free up to the strength of the silicone. See print and post print instructions for print and assembly.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 is fine

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The mold .stl will print normally. The depressions in the bottom are filled with silicone and the top piece is for smoothing the fresh silicone before it sets - which gives a reasonably flat surface to glue to the finger.
To get the best final printed fingertip, stop the printer before the fingertip has finished printing. When the print level has completed all of the bottom features but before the actual tip is printed, the finger is done. This leaves open access to the infill and mount holes which will be filled with fresh silicone when gluing the molded silicone tip to the finger.

Final assembly

To make the silicone tips, use a Q-tip to spread a very thin layer of Vaseline on the finger depressions in the mold. Then fill the depression with silicone (Home Depot, about $6 for a gigantic tube) and smooth flat with the mold top piece. When dry, remove the molded tips and clean them up with scissors and a touch of isopropyl alcohol to keep the Vaseline from spreading around.
Very briefly sand the printed fingertip surface and wipe with the alcohol. Completely fill the fingertip infill and holes with silicone, then place a molded fingertip on top.
When dry (overnight), you will have a clean and effective fingertip that is both a lot less expensive and better looking than the "tippies". Yes, it's more work, but it is a tidy solution for the problem of grip potential.

comments.text: Phoenix Smooth Thumb Tippie added 7/7/16

description.text:
A few of our neighbors and friends (including me) are starting to hit 60, so I designed this simple badge to identify the birthday person. I usually glue a simple pin badge clip (As shown in the picture) onto the back. If I don't have a nice bright filament I will usually paint it gold or sparkling silver.
This one is for 60 years old, but it's easy to edit in Tinkered ( link below) and change it to FiVE for your younger friends as shown in the picture. I show the clip attached, but in the photo it was held with Scotch tape as I need to paint this badge. I wanted to show how it fits.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4uwTARTiVIG

Since Rob is lax in actually naming his characters, these all come from the unofficial "Explain xkcd" website. When printing, I would recommend turning on supports "touching baseplate only", since the slides are small enough that they can print without interior support. You can switch reels when printing to get the right colors, or you could just print the whole things in white and color the characters in with a Sharpie.

print_settings.Notes:: You will notice there are two separate magazine files, the "Tight Fit" version should be used when scaling the model up larger, (say for instance if you wanted to print it so that it fit your hand.)

description.text: Just started learning mesh modeling this summer, and thought this would a fun way to practice. I had fun printing this and thought I'd share. Keep in mind that though I've tried to preserve the major features of the original, my model does lack some of the details. Also, I made the lower half of the gun removable to make printing a little easier.

Printer:

Delta Style Printer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

10 %

Notes:

This model was made in 3ds Max using generic units and I didn't pay any attention to the scale, so it's probably going to come through looking huge when you bring the file into your slicing software of choice. For my print, I set the imported units to inches and set the scale to .05. I set my infill to 10% to save print time and set support's to 80% solid with a 0.3 mm gap between the support and the part.

You will notice there are two separate magazine files, the "Tight Fit" version should be used when scaling the model up larger, (say for instance if you wanted to print it so that it fit your hand.)

Printing Orientation

I already removed the supports in this image, but it does correctly show the orientation I used for printing.

Assembled

The final model came out pretty well, all things considered, but I did still have a fair amount of clean up to do on the bottom edges of both pieces. Part of this is probably due to the failings of my little home brew printer, so if someone does a better job, I'd love to see it!

comments.text: This was one of the first few things I ever modeled in a mesh modeling program so how big is it? I'm not even really sure, but very. If you set the scaling like I mentioned on the page you'll get a print about the size of what I have shown. I really should go back and fix the sizing though on this model. If you would like it in a specific size though, just let me know and I'll upload a version at the size you want.

description.text: 3D Scan version of myself

Process:

1- To take 19 Photos from different angles.
2- Upload these photos to 123Catch
3- Wait A LOT to receive the 3d model (Or use a 3Dscan Software, but my PC sucks...)
4- To import in 3D-Coat and re-touch all the ugly maps (yes, it's worst in the beginning) Save your High Poly version!
5- For retopology export the model to Zbrush (3dCoat is not so good) and use Zremesh and create new UVMaps in Zbrush (or 3DCoat)
6- Now you have a High Poly and a Low Poly Version but the UV Maps are a mess! Let's fix it:
7- Import both models to 3DMax (the high poly version has the original maps and uvs, the Low Poly Version has the UVs from Zbrush or 3DCoat)
8- Align both models, select the Low poly version and use Projection to render a Difuse and Normal map. (You can use Xnormal with similar results)
9- Remix!

This is my generic take on the FatShark Fan button. I just used the KISS method. Mount it to your liking.
1 - 10mm Push button
1 - balance plug to match my battery
1 - short piece of wire for the +
Hot Glue to hold everything together. Not fancy by no means but it does exactly what it needs to do. I pondered how to make a tiny timer and realized there is no need for that. Just a simple push button to turn on the fan. Clear the fog and let go, no 8 to 10 min run. This is to compliment the Faceplate Fat Shark Attitude V2 with Fan by MRracequad, published Dec 30, 2015

Hi!

If you have the Balanced Dice (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:147883), you may need this set of dices.

It's a hollow dice with a solid semisphere in one of the inner faces making it unbalanced.
Sightly increases the probabilities to obtain the 'cheated' number.

I've included 6 dices (cheated for every number)
Also included the 123D-Desing file.

Have fun!

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Supports doesn't matter but recomended to avoid problems printing the top face. Supports will be inside dice and you won't be able to peel off, but doesn't matter.

Tested with PLA at 0.2 resolution.

description.text:
This is Syberia game themed Apple MacBook 2015 stand. The geared design will go nice with my Led bridge lamp. Later there will be nice diorama built in it.

I designed this, because when I work at the desk in my workshop,I needed a way to hold my laptop vertically to have decent WiFi signal. There I have big screen, so I don't need laptop to be open, small screen distracts me, so ... long story short - this is my solution to specifically mine setup. Others will do fine with WiFi extender or stands where screen can be held open. Relation to Syberia game happened unintentially and was realised only when design was complete.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:

Most parts are printed flat, except "geared top" and "arc inside", which should be printed on a side with raft.

Assembly guide

Parts are glued together with acetone. I use small syringe with needle to spread it nicelly on the points, where parts are touchuing each other. I apply acetone two times before pressign parts together. After counting to ten, they are bonded strong enough to continue.

  1. Glue "tower front" and "tower back" to the "side" parts
  2. Glue "arc inside" part to the "side" parts
  3. Glue second "arc" part on top
  4. Finally glue "geared top" part
  5. Put assembly on a platform, check that it fits nicelly, gue it on.

title: X-UAV Mini Talon Parts v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update/Attention!
26 September, 2016

It turns out there are two versions of the GWS S125-1T servo spec'd in this project. One has a 23 tooth spline and one has a 25 tooth spline. You need to find the 25 tooth version to use the coupler in this project. Additionally, the 25 tooth servo has a "Made in Taiwan" label and comes with a black pulley, the 23 tooth has a "Made in China" label and comes with a white pulley. The boxes are identical.

One source for the the correct, 25 tooth servo I found is on ebay. Here is a link:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/162092738102?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Update - All files updated - Aug 9, 2016
So, this second set of Mini Talon parts is based on the cover in the v1 parts and incorporates a servo carriage to hold a GWS S125 1T servo for a solid 360 degree pan. There are two versions of this new cover, the first has just the servo. The second adds a bracket for a Surveilzone HS1177 or an HS1184 FPV camera.

I've made some improvements and added a bit to the GWS version pieces. I've never liked hanging the weight of a camera plus mounts and other gear on the end of a single servo shaft because of the stress and forces this puts on the servo shaft. Especially if you have a poor "landing". The solution? A servo coupler and bearing plate both sold by ServoCity.com. This takes all the stress off the servo and makes for an extremely solid pan platform.

The servo coupler is a 6061 Aluminum piece which has a spline for either Hitec 24t or Futaba 25t. The Futaba coupler fits the GWS servo perfectly. All in all, the coupler, bearing, bearing plate and stand-offs add ~11g. In the picture you'll see nylon stand-offs which I have replaced with aluminum.

Modified the Mobius mount plate, to make it possible to thread the power and video wires down the coupler tube. I also added 4 3mm holes to use as wire tie points. You will also need to make an 2mm x 4mm vertical slot in the coupler tube below the bearing if you want to thread the wires.

Parts for Servo only:
Front_Deck_Cover_plain_GWS_v2.stl
GWS_Bearing_Plate_v2.stl
GWS_Servo_Mount_v3.stl
GWS_Mob_Mount_Short_v6.stl or GWS_Mob_Turret_Mount_v3.stl

Parts for Servo plus FPV camera:
Front_Deck_Cover__nose_cam_GWS_v2.stl
GWS_Bearing_Plate_v2.stl
GWS_Servo_Mount_v3.stl.stl
GWS_Mob_Mount_Short_v6.stl or GWS_Mob_Turret_Mount_v3.stl
HS1177_Cam_Mount_v2.stl or HS1184_Cam_Mount_v3.stl

The extra tabs on the GWS_Servo_Mount_v1.stl are to increase glue area for strength.

I like having the FPV cam in the nose and the Mobius on the pan as I have a camera switch and the Mobius is more slippery in terms of drag. Plus I get a very good recording of looking behind and around :)

Additional hardware:
4x M3 x 15mm Aluminum stand-offs
4x M3 x 8mm Flat head screws
4x M3 x 8mm Nylon Philips head screws
2x M3 x 6mm Screws
2x M3 x 10mm Socket head screws
4x M2.5 x 6mm Screws
4x M2.5 Flat Washers
1x #535024, 3/8” x 5/8” x 0.156” Ball Bearing (servocity.com)
1x #525142, 25T x 0.375”OD x 1.00”L Servo Coupler (servocity.com)

Happy printing!
Mark

All parts are designed to be printed in PLA (no shrinkage factor).

More Mini Talon Parts!
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Mini_Talon_Parts_Compilation

comments.text:
Hello Markqv,
Thanks for sharing these great designs. I would like to use this setup like the 4th and 6th photos. Very low profile, round spline close to the cowl and high servo mount inside. Would any standard size servo fit? And just glue the round spline to the Mobius deck? I'm having a heck of a time trying to source the recommended GWS servo 25 tooth Taiwan version. There are only a few vendors in ebay and they don,t ship to US protectorates, where I am. Are you aware of any alternatives for the servo and coupler? Or if the coupler is not needed then I found a place with the 23 tooth spline china version available.
Regards.
comments.author: prjoe

comments.text:
Hi prjoe,
I just uploaded a printable coupler to the page. This was on the "Heavy Duty Pan & Tilt" page. The name of the file is "Futaba_Servo_Coupler_v2.STL" and it replaces the aluminum coupler as long as you can find a wheel or cross servo arm to bolt it to. The bolt patern on this coupler is for a standard Futaba servo wheel but I'm sure you could adapt it to something else so the 23 tooth JR spline servo should work. You'll still need to have the bearing plate and bearing for this to actually work however as the GWS spline/shaft is very weak by itself.

title: Penny Launcher
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The rubber band powered penny launcher is a staple of engineering inter office warfare. Although it could just be the graduate student research group setting. In any case I saw a few similar disc launcher things but nothing that really suited my needs. This is just a simple version I quickly tossed together. The range is easily across the lab using standard rubber bands double wrapped on each side. For those not in the US, the penny is about 19mm across and 1.55mm thick. Update 3/1/12
Iâ€™ve added a version with fixed geometry. It slices without any errors and warnings for me. If you somehow get an error please let me know.

Print all 3 pieces and assemble with #4-40 screws.  About .5 inch in length is needed.  The front screws need to be tight and the back screws need to be loose so it doesn't jam.
You'll need to make the slider (piece 3) solid so it doesnâ€™t break easily.  Even then they will break occasionally in normal operation.  It's a quick piece to print and replace anyway.

description.text:
Small limit switches are used in robotics and CNC applications. They can be tricky to mount because they only have the two mounting holes. It always seems necessary to come up with some sort of bracket. This bracket can be used in many ways. So you can print up a bunch and keep them with your switch supply.
The large holes are designed for 4-40 hardware, but 3mm should work well. The switch can be mounted with either 2-56 or 2mm hardware.

title: Micro FPV Quadcopter 125 | 8.5mm motors and Micro Scisky
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This quadcopter frame was inspired by the Micro 105 FPV Quadcopter - 8.5mm Motors, Micro Scisky and the SciSky FC (Quanum PICO) in Parrot Frame, but modelled from scratch.
If you need detailled instructions on how to build such a mini quadcopter beast, I suggest you read punkkills instructions.

Important:

Use the "_1.6mm" stl-files, if you know your printer has troubles with inprint between 1.2 and 1.5 mm layer width! Otherwise, the motor mounts might not be as stable as designed.

Changes:

  • Wall width increased from 1.5 to 1.6 mm on motor mounts and sides of inner frame.

Stats:

  • Lightweight: 8 g bottom, 2 g top. My complete setup (see pictures) weighs 43 g. With 750 mah battery it gets to 63 g and ~10 min flight time. 950 mah is also an option to prolong flight time to ~12 min, but you will feel that the quadcopter gets a bit less responsive.

  • Robust: this frame already survived hard impacts. In fact I was not able to destroy one yet :)

  • Motor mounts: I desinged to motor mounts to be very robust, so the motors take no damage during crashes or harsh landings.

  • Micro-Scisky mount: This frame has a built in mount for your Micro-Scisky board to hold it straight in place!

  • Easy USB access: Rear notch to easily plug in your USB cable for programming.

My setup/what you need:

  • 4x 8.5 mm motors + propellers, e.g. Hubsan 107C parts
  • Micro-Scisky/Quanum pico flight controller (+ DSM2 compatible radio)
  • 1s LiPo, > 300mah
  • 4x M3 screw, shaft lenght > 18 mm

Optional:

  • Mini-Camera
  • 5.8 GHz Video Transmitter, e.g. FX MM213TL or TX5813
  • 5.8 GHz antenna
  • 5.8 GHz receiver equipment
  • Foam rubber, for bottom of quadcopter and camera (see pictures) in case of hard crashes

title: Blind Friendly Board Game: Santorini
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Santorini is an abstract board game designed by Mathematician Gordon Hamilton and produced by Roxley Game Laboratory.

For more information about Santorini please visit https://roxley.com/santorini

This version of Santorini utilizes unique shapes so that they are distinguishable by touch and stack within one another. The player pawns are shaped pegs that fit into holes on the building pieces and game board.

Support material will be required for all the building pieces and domes, and glue will be needed to attach the dome pegs to the domes.
quantities for the pieces are:
1 game board
22 base buildings
18 mid buildings
14 top buildings
18 domes
18 dome pegs
and 2 of each pawn

This version of Santorini was developed with permission from Roxley Game Laboratory, and is licensed under Creative Commons - Attribution-NonCommercial-No Derivatives

title: Barbell Weight spacer/ fitter 25, 5, 2.5 lb for 1inch bar

description.text:
Bar bell Weight spacer 25, 5, 2.5 lb fitter for 1inch bar

These parts are designed to make Olympic standard hole diameter weights fit the cheaper 1 inch diameter bars or photography rig bars that you may have around the house.

I have designed a 25lb 2.5lb or 5lb thread on the parts, they are snap in components and can be easily removed by applying key force on more than 3 tabs at the same time. The device easy nest's with others so weights can be stacked.

I am available to customize this component if you need a wider size say for 35-45lb weights. I am not sure if this component will hold more than 25lb's. I strongly recommend printing with 100% infill.

The parts work nicely, we are very happy with them!

This is my minion dave remix, I cut a locating hole and added a locating pin to the design to aid in glueing the two halves together.

After printing the two halves press the locating pin/cube into one half and then press the 2 halves together.

Depending on the accuracy of your printer you may need to sand the cube a little to ensure the two halves completely press together. I added a 0.2mm tolerance to the parts as I know this is what my printer is accurate to. Your milage may vary.

Larger Size:

The inside diameter of the bottom is 180mm, wall thickness 0.5mm, wall height 20mm, ridges 2.5mm high. The angle of the wall is 105 deg from the bottom.

There should be some extra room around the pot for water to pool. X and Y can be scaled differently to better fit odd shaped pots as seen in the second photo.
